javascript.name: JavaScript
javascript.description: Core JavaScript concepts and modern features

hints.title: Difference between == and ===
hints.content: == allows type coercion (e.g., '5' == 5 returns true), while === checks both value and type strictly (e.g., '5' === 5 returns false). Always use === for predictable comparisons.

hints.title: Arrow Functions vs Regular Functions
hints.content: Arrow functions don't have their own 'this' binding - they inherit 'this' from the parent scope. They also can't be used as constructors and don't have a 'prototype' property.

hints.title: Closures
hints.content: A closure is when a function 'remembers' its lexical scope even when executed outside that scope. This allows functions to access variables from their outer scope.

hints.title: Promises
hints.content: Promises represent asynchronous operations with three states: pending, resolved, or rejected. Use .then() for success and .catch() for errors, or async/await for cleaner syntax.

hints.title: Spread vs Rest Operators
hints.content: Spread (...) expands arrays/objects into individual elements. Rest (...) collects multiple elements into an array. Example: spread - [...arr1, ...arr2]; rest - function(...args)

hints.title: Async/Await
hints.content: Async/await is syntactic sugar over Promises. 'async' functions return promises automatically. 'await' pauses execution until the promise resolves. Use try/catch for error handling.

hints.title: ES6 Modules
hints.content: ES6 modules use import/export syntax. Default exports: export default functionName; Named exports: export const name = 'value'. Import: import name from './file' or import { name } from './file'.

hints.title: Template Literals
hints.content: Template literals use backticks and ${} for variable interpolation. They preserve whitespace and allow multi-line strings. Example: `Hello, ${name}! You have ${count} messages.`

hints.title: Destructuring
hints.content: Destructuring extracts values from arrays/objects into variables. Array: const [a, b] = arr; Object: const {name, age} = person. Use rest/spread with destructuring.

hints.title: Hoisting
hints.content: Variable and function declarations are moved to the top of their scope. 'var' declarations are hoisted (initialized with undefined), 'let' and 'const' are hoisted but not initialized (Temporal Dead Zone).

hints.title: Prototypes
hints.content: Every object has a prototype (__proto__) that provides inherited properties and methods. Constructor functions have a prototype property. Use Object.create() to create objects with specific prototypes.

hints.title: Event Loop
hints.content: JavaScript has a single-threaded, non-blocking event loop. Call stack executes synchronous code. Callback queue holds asynchronous callbacks. Event loop processes queue when stack is empty.

hints.title: This Keyword
hints.content: 'this' refers to the object that owns the currently executing code. In methods, 'this' is the object; in functions, 'this' is global/window; in arrow functions, 'this' is inherited from parent scope.

hints.title: Set and Map
hints.content: Set stores unique values, Map stores key-value pairs. Set: const s = new Set([1,2,3]); Map: const m = new Map([['a',1], ['b',2]]). Both maintain insertion order and are iterable.

hints.title: Generators
hints.content: Generator functions use 'function*' and 'yield' to pause/resume execution. They return an iterator object. Use for...of loops to iterate through yielded values. Useful for lazy evaluation and infinite sequences.

hints.title: Symbol Type
hints.content: Symbols are unique and immutable primitives. Use Symbol('description') for object keys to avoid collisions. Well-known symbols like Symbol.iterator enable iteration protocols. Symbols are not enumerable in for...in loops.

hints.title: WeakMap and WeakSet
hints.content: WeakMap and WeakSet hold weak references to objects. Keys in WeakMap must be objects. They don't prevent garbage collection. Use for memory leak prevention, caches, and metadata storage.

hints.title: Proxy Objects
hints.content: Proxy wraps objects and intercepts operations like get, set, has, etc. Use for validation, logging, debugging, or creating reactive systems. Reflect API provides methods to perform default operations.

hints.title: Module Systems
hints.content: CommonJS: require/module.exports (Node.js). ES6 Modules: import/export (modern browsers). AMD: define/require (older browsers). UMD: Universal modules that work everywhere.

hints.title: Event Loop
hints.content: JavaScript is single-threaded but uses event loop for async operations. Call stack executes functions, callback queue holds completed async operations, microtask queue has higher priority (promises).

hints.title: Memory Leaks
hints.content: Common causes: global variables, timers not cleared, event listeners not removed, closures holding references, circular references in DOM. Use tools like Chrome DevTools to identify leaks.

hints.title: BigInt
hints.content: BigInt handles integers larger than 2^53-1. Use 'n' suffix: 123n. Works with +, -, *, /, **, %. Use BigInt() constructor. Useful for database IDs, timestamps, and large calculations.

hints.title: Optional Chaining
hints.content: Optional chaining (?.) safely accesses nested properties without error. Example: user?.address?.street. Returns undefined if any property is null/undefined. Available since ES2020.

hints.title: Nullish Coalescing
hints.content: Nullish coalescing (??) returns right operand if left is null/undefined, otherwise returns left. Different from || which treats 0, '', false as falsy. Example: height ?? 'auto'

hints.title: Logical Assignment
hints.content: Logical assignment operators: ||=, &&=, ??=. Example: a ||= b (a || (a = b)), a ??= b (a ?? (a = b)). Shorthand for common patterns. Available since ES2021.

hints.title: Intl API
hints.content: Internationalization API for formatting numbers, dates, currencies. Use Intl.NumberFormat, Intl.DateTimeFormat, Intl.Collator. Supports locales and formatting options. Essential for global applications.

hints.title: Web Workers
hints.content: Web Workers run JavaScript in background threads. Use for heavy computations without blocking UI. Communication via postMessage. Dedicated workers for specific tasks, shared workers for multiple scripts.

hints.title: Service Workers
hints.content: Service workers intercept network requests, cache resources, enable offline functionality. Lifecycle: install, activate, fetch. Use for PWAs, background sync, push notifications.

hints.title: Web Components
hints.content: Web Components are reusable custom elements. Use CustomElementRegistry, Shadow DOM, HTML Templates. Standards include Custom Elements, Shadow DOM, and ES Modules. Framework agnostic.

hints.title: Performance Optimization
hints.content: Minimize bundle size with code splitting. Use lazy loading for routes and components. Optimize images (WebP, responsive images). Use CDN for static assets. Implement caching strategies.

hints.title: Security Best Practices
hints.content: Never trust user input. Use Content Security Policy (CSP). Sanitize HTML with DOMPurify. Use HTTPS everywhere. Implement proper authentication/authorization. Regular security audits.

hints.title: Testing JavaScript
hints.content: Unit testing with Jest/Vitest. Integration testing with Testing Library. E2E testing with Playwright/Cypress. Test user interactions, edge cases, error scenarios. Use TDD approach.

hints.title: Error Handling
hints.content: Use try/catch for synchronous errors. Handle promise rejections with .catch() or async/await try/catch. Use global error handlers. Log errors with proper context. Implement graceful degradation.

hints.title: Code Organization
hints.content: Use modules for separation of concerns. Follow consistent naming conventions. Use linters (ESLint) and formatters (Prettier). Write self-documenting code with clear variable/function names.

hints.title: Modern JavaScript Features
hints.content: ES2023+ features: Array.prototype.findLast(), Array.prototype.toSorted(), Hashbang grammar. Keep up with TC39 proposals. Use Babel for transpilation. Check browser compatibility.

quiz.question: What will console.log(typeof null) output?
quiz.explanation: 'typeof null' returns 'object' due to a legacy JavaScript bug. This is a well-known quirk that hasn't been fixed for backwards compatibility.

quiz.question: Which of the following is NOT a primitive data type in JavaScript?
quiz.explanation: Array is an object type, not a primitive. JavaScript primitives are: string, number, boolean, undefined, null, symbol, and bigint.

quiz.question: What does 'use strict' do?
options: Enables stricter parsing and error handling
quiz.explanation: 'use strict' enables strict mode, which catches common coding mistakes and prevents the use of potentially problematic features.

quiz.question: What is the output of: [1, 2, 3].map(x => x * 2).filter(x => x > 3)
quiz.explanation: The map function doubles each element to [2, 4, 6], then filter removes elements â‰¤ 3, leaving [4, 6].

quiz.question: Which method creates a new array with all elements that pass a test?
quiz.explanation: filter() creates a new array with all elements that pass the condition specified in the callback function.

quiz.question: What is the output of: Boolean('false')?
quiz.explanation: Boolean('false') returns true because any non-empty string is truthy in JavaScript.

quiz.question: Which of the following is a falsy value?
quiz.explanation: 0, empty string (''), and false are all falsy values in JavaScript.

quiz.question: What does the 'new' keyword do?
quiz.explanation: The 'new' keyword creates an object, calls the constructor function, and sets the prototype of the new object.

quiz.question: What is the difference between null and undefined?
options: null is an object, undefined is a primitive
undefined means not defined, null means no value
undefined is an object, null is a primitive
quiz.explanation: null is explicitly assigned to indicate 'no value', while undefined means the variable has been declared but not assigned a value.

quiz.question: What does JSON.stringify() do?
quiz.explanation: JSON.stringify() converts a JavaScript object or value to a JSON string.

quiz.question: Which method removes the last element from an array?
quiz.explanation: pop() removes the last element from an array and returns it.

quiz.question: What is a closure?
options: A function that returns another function
A function that has access to outer scope variables
A function that closes the browser
quiz.explanation: A closure is a function that has access to variables in its outer (enclosing) scope even after the outer function has returned.

quiz.question: What does 'this' refer to in an arrow function?
quiz.explanation: Arrow functions don't have their own 'this' - they inherit 'this' from the parent scope where they are defined.

quiz.question: Which of the following is NOT a JavaScript data type?
quiz.explanation: JavaScript doesn't have a 'character' data type. Individual characters are strings of length 1.

quiz.question: What is the result of: 3 + '3'?
quiz.explanation: When adding a number and string, JavaScript converts the number to string and concatenates them, resulting in '33'.

quiz.question: Which method removes the last element from an array?
quiz.explanation: pop() removes and returns the last element from an array. push() adds elements to the end.

quiz.question: What does 'use strict' do?
quiz.explanation: 'use strict' enables strict mode, which catches common coding mistakes and prevents unsafe actions.

quiz.question: Which symbol is used for optional chaining?
quiz.explanation: The optional chaining operator (?.) allows reading the value of a property without throwing an error if the reference is null or undefined.

quiz.question: What is a closure?
options: A function with access to outer scope variables
quiz.explanation: A closure is a function that has access to variables in its outer (enclosing) scope even after the outer function has returned.

quiz.question: Which of these is NOT a JavaScript framework?
quiz.explanation: JavaScript is the programming language itself, while React, Angular, and Vue.js are frameworks built on top of it.

quiz.question: What does the 'this' keyword refer to in a regular function?
quiz.explanation: In a regular function, 'this' refers to the object that called the function. In global scope, it refers to the global object (window in browsers).

quiz.question: Which method converts a JSON string to an object?
quiz.explanation: JSON.parse() converts a JSON string to a JavaScript object. JSON.stringify() does the opposite - converts an object to JSON string.

quiz.question: What is the difference between let and var?
options: let is block-scoped, var is function-scoped
var is block-scoped, let is function-scoped
quiz.explanation: let is block-scoped (only available within the block it's declared), while var is function-scoped and can be accessed outside blocks but within functions.

quiz.question: Which operator is used for nullish coalescing?
quiz.explanation: The nullish coalescing operator (??) returns the right operand if the left is null or undefined, otherwise returns the left operand.

quiz.question: What does BigInt do?
quiz.explanation: BigInt is used to represent integers larger than 2^53-1. Use 'n' suffix: 123n. Essential for database IDs and large calculations.

quiz.question: Which method is used to add an element to the beginning of an array?
quiz.explanation: unshift() adds one or more elements to the beginning of an array. push() adds to the end, shift() removes from the beginning.

quiz.question: What is the purpose of a Promise?
quiz.explanation: Promises are used to handle asynchronous operations in JavaScript. They represent a value that may not be available yet.

quiz.question: Which of these is a JavaScript Symbol?
quiz.explanation: Symbol() creates a new unique symbol. Symbols are primitives, so they don't use 'new'. Symbol.create() is not a valid method.

quiz.question: What does the 'async' keyword do?
options: Makes a function return a Promise
quiz.explanation: The 'async' keyword makes a function return a Promise automatically. Async functions can use 'await' to pause execution until a Promise resolves.

quiz.question: Which method is used to find the index of an element in an array?
quiz.explanation: indexOf() returns the first index at which a given element can be found in the array. findIndex() is similar but for more complex searches.

web.name: Web/Frontend
web.description: General web development and frontend concepts

hints.title: CSS Box Model
hints.content: Every element has content, padding, border, and margin. Total width = content + padding-left + padding-right + border-left + border-right + margin-left + margin-right.

hints.title: CSS Specificity
hints.content: Specificity determines which CSS rule applies when multiple rules target the same element. Order: inline styles > IDs > classes/attributes/pseudo-classes > elements/pseudo-elements.

hints.title: DOM Manipulation
hints.content: The Document Object Model represents the page structure. You can select elements with getElementById, querySelector, etc., and modify them with properties like innerHTML, style, classList.

hints.title: Event Bubbling
hints.content: Events propagate from the target element up to the root. Use event.stopPropagation() to prevent this. Event delegation uses bubbling to handle events on parent elements.

hints.title: CSS Flexbox
hints.content: Flexbox is a layout method for arranging items in rows or columns. Use display: flex on container, justify-content for horizontal alignment, align-items for vertical alignment.

hints.title: CSS Grid
hints.content: CSS Grid is a 2D layout system. Use display: grid on container, grid-template-columns/rows to define layout. grid-column/grid-row for item placement. More powerful than Flexbox for complex layouts.

hints.title: CSS Media Queries
hints.content: Media queries apply CSS based on device characteristics. Use @media (max-width: 768px) for mobile styles. Common breakpoints: mobile (768px), tablet (1024px), desktop (1200px+).

hints.title: CSS Transitions
hints.content: Transitions create smooth animations between states. Use transition: property duration timing-function. Common properties: transform, opacity, background-color. Use transform instead of changing dimensions for better performance.

hints.title: CSS Animations
hints.content: @keyframes defines animation steps. Use animation: name duration timing-function iteration-count. Keyframes go from 0% to 100%. Use animation-fill-mode: forwards to keep final state.

hints.title: CSS Variables
hints.content: CSS custom properties (variables) allow reusable values. Define: --primary-color: #007bff; Use: color: var(--primary-color). Change dynamically with JavaScript: element.style.setProperty('--primary-color', '#ff0000').

hints.title: Responsive Design
hints.content: Use relative units (%, em, rem, vw, vh) instead of fixed units. Mobile-first approach: start with mobile styles, then enhance for larger screens. Use CSS Grid/Flexbox for layouts.

hints.title: Semantic HTML
hints.content: Use meaningful HTML elements: <header>, <nav>, <main>, <article>, <section>, <aside>, <footer>. Improves accessibility, SEO, and code readability. Screen readers and search engines understand content better.

hints.title: Accessibility (A11y)
hints.content: Use alt text for images, proper heading hierarchy (h1-h6), sufficient color contrast (4.5:1 ratio). Test with screen readers. Use ARIA labels for dynamic content. Make focus visible and logical.

hints.title: Performance Optimization
hints.content: Minimize HTTP requests, compress images, use CDN. Lazy load images and components. Use CSS/JS minification. Implement caching headers. Avoid render-blocking resources.

hints.title: Progressive Enhancement
hints.content: Build core functionality with HTML/CSS first, then enhance with JavaScript. Ensures site works without JS. Start with basic experience, add features progressively. Better accessibility and performance.

hints.title: Browser Compatibility
hints.content: Test across multiple browsers and versions. Use tools like BrowserStack, Can I Use, or MDN compatibility tables. Use progressive enhancement. Consider polyfills for older browsers.

hints.title: Web Security
hints.content: Use HTTPS everywhere. Implement Content Security Policy (CSP). Sanitize user inputs. Use secure cookies (HttpOnly, Secure, SameSite). Prevent XSS, CSRF, and other attacks.

hints.title: Web Analytics
hints.content: Use Google Analytics, Matomo, or Plausible for tracking. Track page views, user behavior, conversions. Implement event tracking for interactions. Respect user privacy with GDPR compliance.

hints.title: Web Performance Metrics
hints.content: Core Web Vitals: LCP (loading), FID (interactivity), CLS (visual stability). Use Lighthouse, PageSpeed Insights, Chrome DevTools. Monitor with Real User Monitoring (RUM).

hints.title: Mobile-First Design
hints.content: Design for mobile first, then enhance for larger screens. Use responsive breakpoints. Optimize touch targets (44px minimum). Consider thumb-friendly navigation. Test on real devices.

hints.title: API Integration
hints.content: Use fetch() or axios for API calls. Handle loading, success, and error states. Implement proper error handling. Use environment variables for API endpoints. Consider API rate limits.

hints.title: State Management
hints.content: Use React Context, Vuex, Redux, or Zustand for complex state. Keep state local when possible. Use immutable updates. Consider state persistence for user preferences.

hints.title: Component Architecture
hints.content: Build reusable components. Use composition over inheritance. Follow single responsibility principle. Create component libraries. Use design systems like Material Design or Ant Design.

hints.title: Testing Strategies
hints.content: Unit testing: Jest, Vitest. Integration testing: Testing Library. E2E testing: Cypress, Playwright. Visual testing: Percy, Chromatic. Performance testing: Lighthouse CI.

hints.title: Deployment Strategies
hints.content: Use CI/CD pipelines. Deploy to staging first. Use feature flags. Implement blue-green deployments. Monitor error rates. Rollback strategy for failed deployments.

hints.title: Code Quality
hints.content: Use ESLint and Prettier for code consistency. Follow coding standards. Write meaningful commit messages. Use conventional commits. Regular code reviews and pair programming.

hints.title: Design Systems
hints.content: Create reusable component libraries with consistent styling. Use design tokens for colors, typography, spacing. Implement theme switching. Document component usage and props.

hints.title: User Experience
hints.content: Follow UX best practices. Use consistent navigation patterns. Provide clear feedback for user actions. Optimize loading states. Make forms user-friendly with proper validation.

hints.title: Internationalization
hints.content: Use i18n libraries like react-i18next, vue-i18n. Support multiple languages and locales. Handle RTL languages. Consider cultural differences in design and content.

hints.title: Modern Development Tools
hints.content: Use Vite for fast development. Hot Module Replacement for instant updates. Use TypeScript for type safety. Implement proper error boundaries. Use Storybook for component development.

quiz.question: Which CSS property is used to create space between flex items?
quiz.explanation: The 'gap' property creates space between flex items, replacing the need for margins in many cases.

quiz.question: What does CSS specificity 1-0-0 mean?
quiz.explanation: CSS specificity is calculated as (inline styles, IDs, classes/attributes/pseudo-classes, elements/pseudo-elements).

quiz.question: Which method would you use to select the first element with class 'my-class'?
quiz.explanation: querySelector returns the first matching element, while querySelectorAll returns a NodeList of all matching elements.

quiz.question: What is the default position value in CSS?
quiz.explanation: By default, elements have position: static, meaning they flow normally in the document without special positioning.

quiz.question: Which pseudo-class selects an element when the user hovers over it?
quiz.explanation: :hover pseudo-class applies styles when the user hovers over an element with the mouse cursor.

quiz.question: What is the correct way to center a div horizontally and vertically using Flexbox?
options: display: flex; justify-content: center; align-items: center;
display: flex; text-align: center; vertical-align: middle;
quiz.explanation: Using display: flex with justify-content: center and align-items: center centers the content both horizontally and vertically.

quiz.question: Which HTML element is used for navigation links?
quiz.explanation: The <nav> element represents a section of navigation links, which is semantically correct and improves accessibility.

quiz.question: What does CSS 'z-index' property do?
quiz.explanation: z-index controls the stacking order of positioned elements, with higher values appearing in front of lower values.

quiz.question: Which CSS property is used to make text bold?
quiz.explanation: font-weight property controls the thickness of text, with 'bold' or numeric values like 700 making text bold.

quiz.question: What is the purpose of the 'alt' attribute in tags?
options: To provide alternative text for screen readers
quiz.explanation: The alt attribute provides alternative text when the image cannot be displayed, and is crucial for accessibility.

quiz.question: Which of the following is a valid CSS media query?
quiz.explanation: @media screen and (max-width: 768px) is the correct syntax for a media query targeting screens with maximum width of 768px.

quiz.question: What does 'rem' unit represent in CSS?
options: Relative to root element font size
quiz.explanation: 'rem' (root em) is relative to the root element's font size, making it scalable and consistent across the entire document.

quiz.question: Which HTML element is used to create a dropdown list?
quiz.explanation: The <select> element creates a dropdown list, with <option> elements defining the available choices.

quiz.question: What is the correct way to include an external CSS file?
quiz.explanation: The correct way to include an external CSS file is using <link rel='stylesheet' href='styles.css'> in the HTML head section.

quiz.question: Which CSS property is used to create rounded corners?
quiz.explanation: border-radius property is used to create rounded corners on elements, with values like '10px' or '50%' for circles.

quiz.question: What is the purpose of semantic HTML?
quiz.explanation: Semantic HTML uses meaningful elements like <header>, <nav>, <main>, <article> which improve accessibility for screen readers and help search engines understand content structure.

quiz.question: Which HTTP method is used to update existing data?
quiz.explanation: PUT is used to update existing data on the server, while POST is used to create new data. GET retrieves data and DELETE removes data.

quiz.question: What does CSS Grid do?
quiz.explanation: CSS Grid is a layout system that allows creating complex, responsive layouts with rows and columns. It's more powerful than Flexbox for two-dimensional layouts.

quiz.question: What is the purpose of the 'alt' attribute in images?
options: To provide alternative text for accessibility
quiz.explanation: The 'alt' attribute provides alternative text when images can't be displayed and is essential for screen readers to understand image content.

quiz.question: Which of these is NOT a web browser?
quiz.explanation: Node.js is a JavaScript runtime environment, not a web browser. Chrome, Firefox, and Safari are web browsers.

quiz.question: What does 'responsive design' mean?
options: Design that works on all devices
quiz.explanation: Responsive design means creating websites that work well on all device sizes - desktop, tablet, and mobile - using flexible layouts and media queries.

quiz.question: Which CSS property controls text alignment?
quiz.explanation: text-align property controls horizontal text alignment with values like left, center, right, and justify.

quiz.question: What is the purpose of a CDN?
quiz.explanation: CDN (Content Delivery Network) distributes content across multiple servers worldwide to reduce loading times and improve performance.

quiz.question: Which HTML element is used for the main content?
quiz.explanation: The <main> element represents the main content of the document, and there should only be one <main> element per page.

quiz.question: What does HTTPS stand for?
quiz.explanation: HTTPS stands for HyperText Transfer Protocol Secure, which encrypts data sent between the browser and server for security.

quiz.question: Which CSS property creates a flex container?
quiz.explanation: display: flex creates a flex container, enabling flexbox layout with properties like justify-content, align-items, and flex-direction.

quiz.question: What is the purpose of meta tags?
options: To provide metadata about the page
quiz.explanation: Meta tags provide metadata about the HTML document, including description, keywords, viewport settings, and character encoding.

quiz.question: Which JavaScript method fetches data from an API?
quiz.explanation: fetch() is the modern JavaScript method for making HTTP requests to APIs. It returns a Promise and is widely supported in modern browsers.

quiz.question: What does 'mobile-first' design mean?
options: Start with mobile design then enhance
quiz.explanation: Mobile-first design means starting with the mobile layout and then using media queries to enhance the design for larger screens.

quiz.question: Which HTML element creates a navigation menu?
quiz.explanation: The <nav> element is used to define navigation links and is semantic HTML that helps screen readers and search engines understand the page structure.

css.name: CSS
css.description: Cascading Style Sheets fundamentals and advanced features

hints.title: CSS Box Model
hints.content: Every element has content, padding, border, and margin. Total width = content + padding-left + padding-right + border-left + border-right + margin-left + margin-right. Use box-sizing: border-box to include padding/border in element width.

hints.title: CSS Selectors
hints.content: Selectors target elements: element (div), class (.my-class), ID (#my-id), universal (*), attribute ([type='text']). Pseudo-classes (:hover, :focus) and pseudo-elements (::before, ::after) add special states and content.

hints.title: CSS Specificity
hints.content: Specificity determines which rule applies: inline styles (1000), IDs (100), classes/attributes/pseudo-classes (10), elements/pseudo-elements (1). !important overrides everything. Use developer tools to debug specificity issues.

hints.title: CSS Flexbox
hints.content: Flexbox layouts items in rows or columns. Container properties: display: flex, justify-content (horizontal), align-items (vertical). Item properties: flex-grow, flex-shrink, flex-basis. Use flex: 1 for equal-width items.

hints.title: CSS Grid
hints.content: CSS Grid creates 2D layouts. Container: display: grid, grid-template-columns/rows. Items: grid-column, grid-row, grid-area. Named grid areas with grid-template-areas. More powerful than Flexbox for complex layouts.

hints.title: CSS Units
hints.content: Absolute units: px (fixed), pt (print), in, cm. Relative units: % (parent), em (parent font-size), rem (root font-size), vw/vh (viewport), vmin/vmax (smaller/larger viewport dimension). Use relative units for responsive design.

hints.title: CSS Media Queries
hints.content: Apply styles based on device characteristics. @media (max-width: 768px) for mobile. Common breakpoints: 576px (mobile), 768px (tablet), 992px (desktop), 1200px (large desktop). Mobile-first approach: start with mobile styles, enhance for larger screens.

hints.title: CSS Transitions
hints.content: Smooth animations between states. transition: property duration timing-function delay. Common properties: transform, opacity, background-color. Use transform instead of changing dimensions for better performance. Easing functions: ease, ease-in, ease-out, ease-in-out.

hints.title: CSS Animations
hints.content: @keyframes define animation steps from 0% to 100%. animation: name duration timing-function iteration-count direction fill-mode. Use animation-fill-mode: forwards to keep final state. Keyframes can have multiple intermediate steps.

hints.title: CSS Variables
hints.content: Custom properties for reusable values. Define: --primary-color: #007bff; Use: color: var(--primary-color). Change with JavaScript: element.style.setProperty('--primary-color', '#ff0000'). Support fallback values: var(--primary-color, blue).

hints.title: CSS Positioning
hints.content: Static (default): normal flow. Relative: offset from normal position. Absolute: positioned relative to nearest positioned ancestor. Fixed: positioned relative to viewport. Sticky: toggles between relative and fixed based on scroll position.

hints.title: CSS Float and Clear
hints.content: Float removes elements from normal flow, floats them left/right. Use clear to prevent floated elements from affecting other elements. Modern layouts prefer Flexbox/Grid over floats. clearfix hack: ::after { content: ''; display: table; clear: both; }

hints.title: CSS Z-Index
hints.content: Controls stacking order of positioned elements. Higher values appear in front. Only works on positioned elements (relative, absolute, fixed, sticky). z-index: auto follows document order. Use z-index for layering elements like modals, dropdowns, tooltips.

hints.title: CSS Pseudo-elements
hints.content: ::before and ::after create virtual elements. Use content property to add text/icons. ::first-letter styles first letter, ::first-line styles first line. ::selection styles selected text. Combine with pseudo-classes for powerful styling.

hints.title: CSS Custom Properties
hints.content: CSS variables can be scoped to components. Use :root for global variables. Variables cascade and inherit. JavaScript can read/modify them. Support in all modern browsers. Great for theming and maintainable stylesheets.

hints.title: CSS Animations
hints.content: Use @keyframes to define animations. Properties: animation-name, duration, timing-function, delay, iteration-count, direction, fill-mode. Use animation shorthand. Consider prefers-reduced-motion for accessibility.

hints.title: CSS Transitions
hints.content: Transition properties change smoothly over time. Use transition-property, duration, timing-function, delay. Shorthand: transition: all 0.3s ease. Apply to hover states for interactive elements.

hints.title: CSS Grid Advanced
hints.content: Use grid-template-areas for named grid areas. grid-auto-rows/columns for implicit tracks. grid-row/column for item positioning. minmax() for flexible sizing. Subgrid for nested grids.

hints.title: CSS Flexbox Advanced
hints.content: Use flex-grow, flex-shrink, flex-basis. align-self for individual items. order property changes visual order. flex-wrap for multi-line layouts. justify-content and align-items for alignment.

hints.title: CSS Media Queries
hints.content: Use @media for responsive design. Test screen size, orientation, resolution. Combine with logical operators (and, or, not). Use min-width/max-width for mobile-first approach. Consider container queries.

hints.title: CSS Specificity
hints.content: Specificity calculation: inline styles (1,0,0,0), IDs (0,1,0,0), classes/attributes/pseudo-classes (0,0,1,0), elements/pseudo-elements (0,0,0,1). !important overrides all. Use wisely.

hints.title: CSS Box Model
hints.content: Content + padding + border + margin = total size. Use box-sizing: border-box to include padding/border in width/height. margin: auto for centering. box-shadow for depth.

hints.title: CSS Positioning
hints.content: position: static (default), relative (offset from normal position), absolute (relative to positioned parent), fixed (relative to viewport), sticky (relative + fixed behavior).

hints.title: CSS Typography
hints.content: font-family, font-size, font-weight, line-height, letter-spacing, text-align, text-decoration, text-transform. Use web fonts (Google Fonts). Consider font-display: swap for performance.

hints.title: CSS Performance
hints.content: Minify CSS, use critical CSS above the fold. Avoid @import, use link tags. Reduce specificity, use efficient selectors. Consider CSS-in-JS vs separate files. Use CSS custom properties.

hints.title: CSS Architecture
hints.content: BEM methodology: Block__Element--Modifier. SMACSS: Base, Layout, Module, State, Theme. ITCSS: Inverted Triangle CSS. Use CSS modules for component-scoped styles.

hints.title: CSS Preprocessors
hints.content: Sass/SCSS: variables, nesting, mixins, functions, partials. Less: similar to Sass. PostCSS: plugins for autoprefixer, cssnext. Choose based on project needs and team familiarity.

hints.title: CSS Accessibility
hints.content: Ensure sufficient color contrast (4.5:1 ratio). Don't rely on color alone to convey meaning. Use focus indicators. Consider prefers-reduced-motion. Test with screen readers.

hints.title: CSS Best Practices
hints.content: Use semantic class names, avoid deep nesting. Follow mobile-first approach. Use CSS reset or normalize. Consistent naming conventions. Document your CSS with comments.

hints.title: CSS Modern Features
hints.content: CSS Container Queries, CSS Subgrid, CSS Logical Properties, CSS Custom Properties (variables), CSS Grid Level 2, CSS Color Level 5. Keep up with modern CSS specifications.

quiz.question: Which CSS property is used to create space between flex items?
quiz.explanation: The 'gap' property creates space between flex items, replacing the need for margins in many cases.

quiz.question: What does CSS specificity 1-0-0 mean?
quiz.explanation: CSS specificity is calculated as (inline styles, IDs, classes/attributes/pseudo-classes, elements/pseudo-elements).

quiz.question: Which CSS property creates a 2D grid layout?
quiz.explanation: display: grid creates a grid container, allowing you to place items in rows and columns.

quiz.question: What is the default value of the 'position' property?
quiz.explanation: By default, elements have position: static, meaning they flow normally in the document without special positioning.

quiz.question: Which pseudo-class selects an element when the user hovers over it?
quiz.explanation: :hover pseudo-class applies styles when the user hovers over an element with the mouse cursor.

quiz.question: What is the correct way to center a div horizontally and vertically using Flexbox?
options: display: flex; justify-content: center; align-items: center;
display: flex; text-align: center; vertical-align: middle;
quiz.explanation: Using display: flex with justify-content: center and align-items: center centers the content both horizontally and vertically.

quiz.question: Which CSS property is used to make text bold?
quiz.explanation: font-weight property controls the thickness of text, with 'bold' or numeric values like 700 making text bold.

quiz.question: What does 'rem' unit represent in CSS?
options: Relative to root element font size
quiz.explanation: 'rem' (root em) is relative to the root element's font size, making it scalable and consistent across the entire document.

quiz.question: Which CSS property is used to create rounded corners?
quiz.explanation: border-radius property is used to create rounded corners on elements, with values like '10px' or '50%' for circles.

quiz.question: What is the purpose of CSS media queries?
options: To apply styles based on device characteristics
quiz.explanation: Media queries allow you to apply CSS styles based on device characteristics like screen size, resolution, and orientation.

quiz.question: Which CSS property controls the stacking order of elements?
quiz.explanation: z-index controls the stacking order of positioned elements, with higher values appearing in front of lower values.

quiz.question: What does the 'flex' shorthand property do?
quiz.explanation: The flex shorthand sets flex-grow, flex-shrink, and flex-basis in one declaration, commonly used as 'flex: 1' for equal-width items.

quiz.question: Which CSS pseudo-element creates content before an element?
quiz.explanation: ::before creates a pseudo-element before the selected element's content. Use with the content property to add text or icons.

quiz.question: What is the correct syntax for defining a CSS custom property?
quiz.explanation: CSS custom properties are defined in :root or any selector using --property-name: value syntax.

quiz.question: Which CSS property is used to create smooth transitions?
quiz.explanation: The transition property creates smooth animations between different states of an element when a property changes.

quiz.question: What does 'display: none' do?
quiz.explanation: display: none removes the element from the document flow completely - it takes up no space and is not visible.

quiz.question: Which CSS property creates a shadow effect?
quiz.explanation: Both box-shadow (for elements) and text-shadow (for text) create shadow effects in CSS.

quiz.question: What is CSS specificity order?
quiz.explanation: CSS specificity is calculated as (IDs, Classes/Attributes/Pseudo-classes, Elements/Pseudo-elements). Higher specificity wins.

quiz.question: Which CSS unit is relative to viewport width?
quiz.explanation: vw (viewport width) is relative to 1% of the viewport width. vh is viewport height, vmin/vmax for smallest/largest dimension.

quiz.question: What does 'position: absolute' do?
quiz.explanation: position: absolute positions an element relative to its nearest positioned ancestor (not static). If no positioned parent, it uses the document body.

quiz.question: Which CSS property controls text color?
quiz.explanation: The color property sets the color of text content in an element.

quiz.question: What is the correct CSS Grid syntax?
quiz.explanation: display: grid creates a grid container where you can place child elements in rows and columns.

quiz.question: Which CSS property creates rounded corners?
quiz.explanation: border-radius creates rounded corners on elements. Use values like '10px' or '50%' for circles.

quiz.question: What does 'z-index' control?
quiz.explanation: z-index controls the stacking order of positioned elements, with higher values appearing in front of lower values.

quiz.question: Which CSS property centers content horizontally?
quiz.explanation: margin: 0 auto centers block-level elements horizontally when they have a defined width.

quiz.question: What is CSS-in-JS?
quiz.explanation: CSS-in-JS allows writing CSS styles directly in JavaScript code, often used in React and other component-based frameworks.

quiz.question: Which CSS property makes text bold?
quiz.explanation: font-weight: bold makes text bold. Other values include normal, lighter, and numeric values (100-900).

quiz.question: What does 'box-sizing: border-box' do?
options: Includes padding and border in element size
Excludes padding and border from element size

quiz.question: Which CSS property controls element transparency?
quiz.explanation: opacity controls element transparency, with values from 0 (fully transparent) to 1 (fully opaque).

quiz.question: What is the CSS cascade?
quiz.explanation: The CSS cascade determines which CSS rules apply when multiple rules target the same element, based on specificity, importance, and source order.

html.name: HTML
html.description: HyperText Markup Language fundamentals and semantic elements

hints.title: HTML Document Structure
hints.content: Every HTML document needs <!DOCTYPE html>, <html>, <head>, and <body>. Head contains meta tags, title, and links to CSS/JS. Body contains visible content. Use <meta charset='UTF-8'> for proper character encoding.

hints.title: Semantic HTML Elements
hints.content: Use meaningful elements: <header>, <nav>, <main>, <article>, <section>, <aside>, <footer>. Improves accessibility, SEO, and code readability. Screen readers and search engines understand content structure better.

hints.title: HTML Forms
hints.content: Forms use <form> element with action and method. Input types: text, email, password, number, date, file, radio, checkbox, submit. Use <label> for accessibility. Validate with required, pattern, min/max attributes.

hints.title: HTML Tables
hints.content: Use <table>, <thead>, <tbody>, <tr>, <th>, <td>. thead for headers, tbody for data. Use colspan/rowspan for merged cells. caption element for table description. Tables should be used for tabular data only.

hints.title: HTML Lists
hints.content: Unordered lists: <ul> with <li>. Ordered lists: <ol> with <li>. Definition lists: <dl> with <dt> (term) and <dd> (description). Nested lists possible. Use CSS for custom styling.

hints.title: HTML Images
hints.content: Use with src, alt (required for accessibility), width/height. Responsive images: srcset for different sizes, sizes attribute. Use picture element for art direction. Always include alt text for screen readers.

hints.title: HTML Links
hints.content: Use <a> with href attribute. Internal links: href='#section' or href='page.html'. External links: href='https://example.com'. Email links: href='mailto:email@example.com'. Download links: href='file.pdf' download.

hints.title: HTML5 Semantic Elements
hints.content: New elements: <article>, <aside>, <details>, <figcaption>, <figure>, <header>, <footer>, <main>, <mark>, <nav>, <section>, <summary>, <time>. Improves document structure and accessibility.

hints.title: HTML Attributes
hints.content: Attributes provide additional information: id (unique identifier), class (CSS styling), style (inline CSS), title (tooltip), data-* (custom data). Boolean attributes like disabled, required, checked don't need values.

hints.title: HTML Accessibility
hints.content: Use alt text for images, proper heading hierarchy (h1-h6), semantic HTML, ARIA labels for dynamic content. Ensure sufficient color contrast (4.5:1 ratio). Test with keyboard navigation and screen readers.

hints.title: HTML5 Media Elements
hints.content: Audio: <audio> with <source> elements. Video: <video> with controls, autoplay, muted attributes. Use multiple <source> elements for different formats (mp4, webm, ogg). Include fallback content.

hints.title: HTML5 Form Elements
hints.content: New input types: email, url, tel, search, range, color, date, time, datetime-local, month, week. Use <datalist> for autocomplete. <fieldset> groups related controls. <legend> describes fieldset.

hints.title: HTML Entities
hints.content: HTML entities represent special characters: & (ampersand), < (less than), > (greater than), " (quotation mark), ' (apostrophe),   (non-breaking space). Use &#number; for numeric codes, &#xhex; for hexadecimal codes.

hints.title: HTML5 Canvas
hints.content: <canvas> element for graphics. Use JavaScript Canvas API: getContext('2d'), methods like fillRect(), strokeRect(), arc(), lineTo(). Ideal for charts, games, image manipulation. Fallback content for non-supporting browsers.

hints.title: HTML Meta Tags
hints.content: Meta tags in <head>: charset for encoding, viewport for responsive design, description/keywords for SEO. Open Graph tags for social media sharing. Use <meta name='robots' content='noindex'> to prevent search indexing.

hints.title: HTML5 Semantic Elements
hints.content: Use <header>, <nav>, <main>, <article>, <section>, <aside>, <footer> for better structure. Improves accessibility, SEO, and code readability. Screen readers and search engines understand content better.

hints.title: HTML Forms
hints.content: Use <form>, <input>, <select>, <textarea>, <button>. Input types: text, email, password, number, date, file. Use labels for accessibility. Validate with HTML5 attributes (required, pattern, min/max).

hints.title: HTML5 Audio/Video
hints.content: <audio> and <video> elements with controls attribute. Multiple source formats for compatibility. Use preload for performance. Fallback content for non-supporting browsers. Consider accessibility with captions.

hints.title: HTML5 Web Storage
hints.content: localStorage (persistent) and sessionStorage (session-only). Use setItem(), getItem(), removeItem(), clear(). JSON.parse/stringify for objects. Check storage quotas and handle errors gracefully.

hints.title: HTML5 Geolocation
hints.content: navigator.geolocation.getCurrentPosition() for current location. watchPosition() for tracking. Handle errors (permission denied, unavailable). Use with maps for location-based features.

hints.title: HTML5 Drag and Drop
hints.content: draggable='true' on elements. Events: dragstart, dragover, drop. dataTransfer object for data exchange. Use preventDefault() on dragover to allow dropping. Visual feedback during drag operations.

hints.title: HTML5 Web Workers
hints.content: Run JavaScript in background threads. new Worker('worker.js'). Communication via postMessage(). Won't block UI. Use for heavy computations, file processing, or real-time data handling.

hints.title: HTML5 WebSockets
hints.content: Real-time communication between client and server. new WebSocket('ws://...'). Events: open, message, error, close. Send/receive data instantly. Use for chat apps, live updates, gaming.

hints.title: HTML5 Service Workers
hints.content: Intercept network requests, cache resources, enable offline functionality. Lifecycle: install, activate, fetch. Use for Progressive Web Apps. Handle background sync and push notifications.

hints.title: HTML5 Notification API
hints.content: Notification.requestPermission() for user consent. new Notification('title', options). Handle click events. Check notification support. Use responsibly to avoid spam.

hints.title: HTML5 Intersection Observer
hints.content: Watch elements entering/leaving viewport. new IntersectionObserver(callback, options). Use for lazy loading, infinite scroll, animations. Better performance than scroll event listeners.

hints.title: HTML5 Resize Observer
hints.content: Watch element size changes. new ResizeObserver(callback). Use for responsive layouts, chart resizing, dynamic content. Better than window resize events for specific elements.

hints.title: HTML5 Mutation Observer
hints.content: Watch DOM changes. new MutationObserver(callback). Monitor childList, attributes, subtree. Use for dynamic content, third-party scripts, debugging. Avoid infinite loops.

hints.title: HTML5 Performance
hints.content: Use <link rel='preload'> for critical resources. Implement lazy loading with loading='lazy'. Use resource hints: dns-prefetch, preconnect, prefetch. Monitor with Performance API.

hints.title: HTML5 Security
hints.content: Use Content Security Policy (CSP) headers. Sanitize user inputs. Use HTTPS everywhere. Implement secure headers: X-Frame-Options, X-Content-Type-Options. Regular security audits and updates.

quiz.explanation: The <main> element represents the main content of the document, excluding headers, footers, and sidebars.

quiz.question: Which element creates a hyperlink?

quiz.question: What does the 'lang' attribute specify?

quiz.question: Which element is used for navigation links?

quiz.question: What is the correct way to create an ordered list?

quiz.question: Which attribute makes a form field required?

quiz.question: What is the purpose of the 'alt' attribute?
options: To provide alternative text for accessibility

quiz.question: Which element creates a table?

quiz.question: What does the 'method' attribute specify in a form?

quiz.question: Which element is used to group form controls?

quiz.question: What is the correct way to create a dropdown list?

quiz.question: Which attribute is used for two-way data binding in Angular?

quiz.question: What is the purpose of the 'action' attribute in a form?

quiz.question: Which element represents a self-contained piece of content?
quiz.explanation: The <article> element represents a self-contained piece of content that could be independently distributed or reused.

quiz.question: What does the 'lang' attribute do?
quiz.explanation: The lang attribute specifies the language of the document's content, important for accessibility and search engines.

quiz.question: Which element creates a navigation menu?
quiz.explanation: The <nav> element is used to define navigation links and is semantic HTML that helps screen readers understand the page structure.

quiz.question: What is the purpose of the 'alt' attribute?
quiz.explanation: The 'alt' attribute provides alternative text for images when they can't be displayed, essential for accessibility.

quiz.question: Which element is used for the main content?
quiz.explanation: The <main> element represents the main content of the document and should only appear once per page.

quiz.question: What does 'semantic HTML' mean?
quiz.explanation: Semantic HTML uses meaningful elements like <header>, <nav>, <main>, <article> that describe their content and purpose.

quiz.question: Which element creates a dropdown list?
quiz.explanation: The <select> element creates a dropdown list with <option> elements defining the available choices.

quiz.question: What is the correct way to include external CSS?
quiz.explanation: The correct way to include external CSS is <link rel='stylesheet' href='styles.css'> in the HTML head.

quiz.question: Which element is used for page header?
quiz.explanation: The <header> element represents introductory content or navigation links at the top of a page or section.

quiz.question: What does 'responsive design' require?
quiz.explanation: Responsive design requires the meta viewport tag <meta name='viewport' content='width=device-width, initial-scale=1'> for proper mobile rendering.

quiz.question: Which element creates a numbered list?
quiz.explanation: <ol> creates an ordered (numbered) list, while <ul> creates an unordered (bulleted) list.

quiz.question: What is the purpose of meta tags?
quiz.explanation: Meta tags provide metadata about the HTML document, including description, keywords, viewport, and character encoding.

quiz.question: Which element is used for page footer?
quiz.explanation: The <footer> element represents footer content at the bottom of a page or section.

quiz.question: What does 'DOCTYPE' do?
quiz.explanation: DOCTYPE declaration tells the browser which version of HTML the document is using, ensuring proper rendering.

quiz.question: Which element creates a clickable button?
quiz.explanation: <button> creates a clickable button. <input type='button'> is also valid but <button> is more flexible and semantic.

quiz.question: What is the purpose of ARIA attributes?
quiz.explanation: ARIA (Accessible Rich Internet Applications) attributes provide additional information to assistive technologies like screen readers.

testing.name: Testing
testing.description: Software testing fundamentals and modern testing practices

hints.title: Unit Testing
hints.content: Unit testing tests individual functions or components in isolation. Use frameworks like Jest, Vitest, Mocha. Focus on testing one thing at a time. Mock external dependencies. Write tests before code (TDD) or after (BDD).

hints.title: Integration Testing
hints.content: Integration testing verifies that multiple components work together correctly. Test component interactions, API calls, and data flow. Use Testing Library for DOM testing. Test both happy paths and error scenarios.

hints.title: E2E Testing
hints.content: End-to-end testing simulates real user scenarios. Use Cypress, Playwright, or Selenium. Tests entire application workflows. More expensive to run but catches integration issues. Use for critical user journeys.

hints.title: Test Doubles
hints.content: Test doubles replace real dependencies in tests. Stubs provide canned answers. Spies record function calls. Mocks replace entire objects. Fakes are simplified implementations. Use them to isolate code under test.

hints.title: Code Coverage
hints.content: Measures how much of your code is tested. Tools: Istanbul, c8, nyc. Types: statement, branch, function, line coverage. Aim for 80%+ coverage. Don't focus only on coverage numbers - test quality matters more.

hints.title: Testing Library
hints.content: Testing Library focuses on testing user behavior, not implementation details. Use getByRole, getByText, getByTestId. Avoid testing internal state. Tests should resemble how users interact with the application.

hints.title: Jest Framework
hints.content: Jest is a popular JavaScript testing framework. Features: zero config, built-in assertions, mocking, snapshot testing. Use describe blocks for test suites, it/test for individual tests. Global setup and teardown with beforeAll/afterAll.

hints.title: Vitest
hints.content: Vitest is a fast unit test framework powered by Vite. ESM-first, TypeScript support out of box, fast HMR in tests. Similar API to Jest. Great for Vite-based projects. Use vitest/ui for visual test interface.

hints.title: Cypress
hints.content: Cypress is an E2E testing framework. Real-time reloading, automatic waiting, network stubbing. Write tests in JavaScript. Use cy.get(), cy.click(), cy.should(). Great developer experience with time travel debugging.

hints.title: Playwright
hints.content: Playwright is a modern E2E testing framework. Cross-browser support (Chrome, Firefox, Safari, Edge). Mobile emulation, network interception. Write tests in TypeScript/JavaScript. Faster than Selenium with better reliability.

hints.title: Mocking
hints.content: Replace real dependencies with controlled substitutes. Jest: jest.mock(), jest.fn(). Sinon: sinon.stub(), sinon.spy(). Benefits: faster tests, predictable behavior, isolate code under test. Mock what you don't own.

hints.title: Test-Driven Development (TDD)
hints.content: Write tests before implementing features. Red-Green-Refactor cycle: write failing test, make it pass, improve code. Benefits: better design, confidence in changes, documentation. Use with pair programming for best results.

hints.title: Behavior-Driven Development (BDD)
hints.content: Focus on behavior rather than implementation. Use Given-When-Then format. Tools: Cucumber, Jest with describe/it. Tests become living documentation. Better collaboration between developers and stakeholders.

hints.title: Performance Testing
hints.content: Measure application speed and resource usage. Tools: Lighthouse, WebPageTest, Chrome DevTools. Test load times, memory leaks, CPU usage. Set performance budgets. Monitor in production with Real User Monitoring (RUM).

hints.title: Accessibility Testing
hints.content: Ensure applications are usable by people with disabilities. Tools: axe-core, Lighthouse accessibility audit, screen readers. Test keyboard navigation, color contrast, alt text. Follow WCAG guidelines. Automate with axe-playwright.

hints.title: Test-Driven Development
hints.content: Write tests before code. Red-Green-Refactor cycle. Tests act as documentation and safety net. Improves code quality and confidence. Use Jest/Vitest with frameworks like React Testing Library or Vue Test Utils.

hints.title: Behavior-Driven Development
hints.content: Write tests in natural language using Gherkin. Tools: Cucumber, SpecFlow. Scenarios: Given-When-Then format. Bridge gap between business and technical teams. Living documentation for features.

hints.title: Test Data Management
hints.content: Use factories, builders, or fixtures for test data. Keep data isolated between tests. Use realistic but anonymized data. Consider data cleanup strategies. Mock external dependencies.

hints.title: Continuous Integration Testing
hints.content: Run tests on every commit. Use GitHub Actions, GitLab CI, Jenkins. Test in multiple environments. Fail fast on test failures. Use parallel execution for speed. Monitor test suite health.

hints.title: Visual Regression Testing
hints.content: Detect UI changes automatically. Tools: Percy, Chromatic, Applitools. Take screenshots, compare against baseline. Catch unintended visual changes. Essential for design system maintenance.

hints.title: API Testing
hints.content: Test REST/GraphQL endpoints. Tools: Postman, Insomnia, Supertest. Test CRUD operations, authentication, error handling. Mock servers with json-server or MSW. Validate response schemas.

hints.title: Database Testing
hints.content: Test data persistence, migrations, queries. Use test databases with known state. Test transactions, rollbacks. Mock databases for unit tests. Validate data integrity and relationships.

hints.title: Security Testing
hints.content: Test for vulnerabilities: XSS, CSRF, SQL injection, authentication bypass. Use tools like OWASP ZAP, Snyk. Implement security headers. Test authorization at every level. Regular dependency audits.

hints.title: Load Testing
hints.content: Test application under heavy load. Tools: Apache JMeter, k6, Artillery. Simulate multiple users, measure response times. Identify bottlenecks. Set realistic load scenarios based on expected traffic.

hints.title: Cross-Browser Testing
hints.content: Test across different browsers and versions. Use BrowserStack, Sauce Labs, or local VMs. Test JavaScript compatibility, CSS rendering, form behavior. Consider mobile browsers and devices.

hints.title: Mobile Testing
hints.content: Test on real devices and emulators. Use Appium for native apps, WebDriver for web. Test touch interactions, screen sizes, network conditions. Consider device-specific features like camera, GPS.

hints.title: Test Reporting
hints.content: Generate comprehensive test reports. Use Allure, TestNG reports, or custom dashboards. Include screenshots, logs, performance metrics. Share with team and stakeholders. Track test trends over time.

hints.title: Test Automation Best Practices
hints.content: Use Page Object Model for UI tests. Implement proper waits (explicit, not implicit). Test data should be separate from tests. Use descriptive test names. Group related tests. Clean up after tests.

hints.title: Testing in Production
hints.content: Monitor real user behavior with analytics. Use feature flags for controlled rollouts. Implement canary releases. Monitor error rates and performance. Gather user feedback on new features.

hints.title: Test Strategy Planning
hints.content: Define testing scope, objectives, and timelines. Choose appropriate testing types for each feature. Plan for test environments and data. Define success criteria. Consider risk-based testing approaches.

quiz.question: What does CI/CD stand for?

quiz.question: Which testing level tests the interaction between components?

apis.description: REST APIs, authentication, and data management concepts

hints.title: REST API Basics
hints.content: REST (Representational State Transfer) uses HTTP methods: GET (read), POST (create), PUT (update), PATCH (partial update), DELETE (remove). Use proper status codes: 200 OK, 201 Created, 400 Bad Request, 401 Unauthorized, 404 Not Found, 500 Server Error.

hints.title: Fetch API
hints.content: Native JavaScript API for making HTTP requests. Use fetch(url, options) with options: method, headers, body. Returns Promise. Handle responses with .then() or async/await. Always handle errors with try/catch.

hints.title: Axios Library
hints.content: Popular HTTP client with better error handling, request/response interceptors, automatic JSON parsing. Use axios.get(), axios.post(), etc. Better browser support than fetch. Built-in request cancellation with CancelToken.

hints.title: CRUD Operations
hints.content: Create, Read, Update, Delete operations. Map to HTTP methods: C=POST, R=GET, U=PUT/PATCH, D=DELETE. Use consistent API endpoints: /api/users (GET=read all, POST=create), /api/users/:id (GET=read one, PUT=update, DELETE=remove).

hints.title: JSON Handling
hints.content: JavaScript Object Notation for data exchange. Use JSON.stringify() to convert objects to JSON, JSON.parse() to convert JSON to objects. Handle large JSON with streaming parsers. Validate JSON before parsing.

hints.title: API Authentication
hints.content: Secure API access with authentication. Basic Auth: username:password in base64. Bearer tokens: Authorization: Bearer token. API keys: custom headers. Always send credentials over HTTPS. Store tokens securely.

hints.title: JWT Tokens
hints.content: JSON Web Tokens contain user information and expiration. Three parts: Header.Payload.Signature. Decode payload to get user info. Verify signature for authenticity. Store in localStorage/sessionStorage, not cookies for XSS protection.

hints.title: OAuth 2.0
hints.content: Authorization framework for delegated access. Flows: Authorization Code (server-side apps), Implicit (SPAs), Client Credentials (server-to-server). Uses access tokens and refresh tokens. Popular with social logins (Google, Facebook, GitHub).

hints.title: Error Handling
hints.content: Handle API errors gracefully. Check response.ok or status codes. Use try/catch for network errors. Show user-friendly error messages. Implement retry logic with exponential backoff. Log errors for debugging.

hints.title: Rate Limiting
hints.content: APIs limit requests to prevent abuse. Check rate limit headers: X-RateLimit-Limit, X-RateLimit-Remaining, X-RateLimit-Reset. Implement client-side throttling. Use exponential backoff for retries. Handle 429 (Too Many Requests) status.

hints.title: CORS
hints.content: Cross-Origin Resource Sharing allows browsers to make requests to different domains. Server must send Access-Control-Allow-Origin header. Preflight requests for non-simple methods (PUT, DELETE). Use credentials: 'include' for cookies.

hints.title: GraphQL
hints.content: Query language for APIs. Request only needed data with single endpoint. Use queries for reading, mutations for writing, subscriptions for real-time. Better for mobile apps with limited bandwidth. Tools: Apollo Client, Relay.

hints.title: API Caching
hints.content: Cache API responses to improve performance and reduce server load. Use browser cache, Service Workers, or libraries like SWR, React Query. Set appropriate cache headers: Cache-Control, ETag, Last-Modified. Invalidate cache when data changes.

hints.title: WebSocket APIs
hints.content: Real-time bidirectional communication. Use for live chat, notifications, live updates. ws:// for unencrypted, wss:// for encrypted. Event-driven with onmessage, onopen, onclose, onerror. Use Socket.IO for fallbacks and room management.

hints.title: API Documentation
hints.content: Document APIs for developers. Tools: Swagger/OpenAPI, Postman Collections, GraphQL Playground. Include request/response examples, authentication methods, error codes. Use API versioning for breaking changes. Test endpoints regularly.

hints.title: GraphQL Basics
hints.content: Query language for APIs. Single endpoint for all data. Clients specify exactly what data they need. Strongly typed schema. Use fragments for reusable selections. Mutations for data changes, subscriptions for real-time data.

hints.title: API Rate Limiting
hints.content: Control API usage to prevent abuse. Implement token bucket or sliding window algorithms. Return 429 status for rate exceeded. Use headers: X-RateLimit-Limit, X-RateLimit-Remaining, X-RateLimit-Reset. Consider different limits for different endpoints.

hints.title: API Caching Strategies
hints.content: Use HTTP caching headers: Cache-Control, ETag, Last-Modified. Implement Redis or Memcached for server-side caching. Use CDN for static assets. Consider cache invalidation strategies. Monitor cache hit rates.

hints.title: Microservices Architecture
hints.content: Break applications into small, independent services. Each service has its own database and API. Use service discovery (Consul, Eureka). Implement circuit breakers for fault tolerance. Use message queues for async communication.

hints.title: API Gateway
hints.content: Single entry point for all client requests. Handles authentication, rate limiting, logging, routing. Tools: Kong, Express Gateway, AWS API Gateway. Offloads common concerns from individual services.

hints.title: OAuth 2.0
hints.content: Authorization framework for secure API access. Flows: Authorization Code, Implicit, Resource Owner Password Credentials, Client Credentials. Use for third-party integrations. Implement refresh tokens for long-lived access.

hints.title: JSON Web Tokens (JWT)
hints.content: Compact, self-contained tokens for securely transmitting information. Contains header, payload, signature. Use for stateless authentication. Store in localStorage or httpOnly cookies. Verify signatures server-side.

hints.title: API Monitoring
hints.content: Monitor API performance, availability, and usage. Tools: Datadog, New Relic, Prometheus. Track response times, error rates, throughput. Set up alerts for anomalies. Monitor business metrics like conversion rates.

hints.title: API Testing
hints.content: Test REST/GraphQL endpoints. Tools: Postman, Insomnia, Supertest. Test CRUD operations, authentication, error handling. Mock external dependencies. Validate response schemas and status codes.

hints.title: API Security
hints.content: Implement HTTPS everywhere. Use API keys or OAuth for authentication. Rate limiting to prevent abuse. Input validation and sanitization. Use CORS appropriately. Regular security audits and penetration testing.

hints.title: Database Design
hints.content: Choose appropriate database: SQL (PostgreSQL, MySQL) for relational data, NoSQL (MongoDB, Redis) for flexible schemas. Normalize data to reduce redundancy. Use indexes for query performance. Consider ACID vs BASE properties.

hints.title: Data Validation
hints.content: Validate incoming data on server side. Use libraries like Joi, Yup, or express-validator. Sanitize inputs to prevent injection attacks. Provide meaningful error messages. Consider client-side validation for better UX.

hints.title: Error Handling
hints.content: Use appropriate HTTP status codes: 200 OK, 400 Bad Request, 401 Unauthorized, 404 Not Found, 500 Internal Server Error. Provide detailed error messages in development, generic ones in production. Log errors for debugging.

hints.title: API Versioning
hints.content: Version APIs to maintain backward compatibility. Strategies: URL versioning (/api/v1/users), header versioning (Accept: application/vnd.api.v1+json), parameter versioning (?version=1). Deprecate old versions with warnings.

hints.title: Scalability Considerations
hints.content: Design for horizontal scaling. Use load balancers. Implement database sharding or partitioning. Cache expensive operations. Use async processing for heavy tasks. Monitor performance metrics and set up auto-scaling.

vue.description: Vue.js framework concepts and best practices

hints.title: Composition API vs Options API
hints.content: Composition API groups related logic together using composables, making it easier to reuse logic across components. Options API separates concerns by options (data, methods, computed, etc.).

hints.title: Reactivity
hints.content: Vue's reactivity system tracks changes to data and updates the DOM automatically. Use ref() for primitives and reactive() for objects. Always access ref values with .value in setup.

hints.title: Lifecycle Hooks
hints.content: onMounted, onUpdated, onUnmounted are the main lifecycle hooks in Composition API. Options API uses mounted, updated, beforeUnmount, etc. Use these to run code at specific points in component lifecycle.

hints.title: Computed Properties
hints.content: Computed properties cache their result and only recalculate when dependencies change. Use them for derived state that depends on reactive data. They're more efficient than methods for expensive operations.

hints.title: Props and Emits
hints.content: Props are reactive data passed from parent to child. Define them with prop types for validation. Emits are events sent from child to parent. Use defineEmits to declare them in Composition API.

hints.title: Vue Router
hints.content: Vue Router handles client-side routing. Use <router-view> to display routes, <router-link> for navigation. Define routes with path, component, and name. Use :to prop with params for dynamic routes.

hints.title: Vuex vs Pinia
hints.content: Vuex is the traditional state management library. Pinia is the new recommended state management with simpler API, TypeScript support, and better developer experience. Use stores, getters, and actions.

hints.title: Watch vs WatchEffect
hints.content: watch() watches specific reactive sources and runs when they change. watchEffect() automatically tracks dependencies and runs when any reactive source changes. Use watch for side effects, watchEffect for reactive effects.

hints.title: Directives
hints.content: Vue directives modify DOM behavior. v-if/v-else conditionally renders elements. v-for renders lists. v-bind binds attributes, v-on attaches event listeners. v-model creates two-way binding.

hints.title: Components Communication
hints.content: Parent to child: props. Child to parent: emit events. Sibling components: event bus or state management. Deep nesting: provide/inject. Global state: Vuex/Pinia stores.

hints.title: Slots
hints.content: Slots allow parent components to pass content to child components. Named slots target specific areas. Scoped slots pass data from child to slot content. Use slot props to access child data.

hints.title: Mixins vs Composables
hints.content: Mixins merge options from multiple sources, can cause conflicts. Composables are functions that use Composition API, more flexible and reusable. Prefer composables over mixins for new projects.

hints.title: Async Components
hints.content: Use defineAsyncComponent() for lazy loading. Suspense component handles loading states. Error boundaries catch component errors. Use dynamic imports for code splitting and better performance.

hints.title: Vue 3 Features
hints.content: Vue 3 brings Composition API, better TypeScript support, Teleport for rendering outside component tree, Suspense for async components, improved performance, and better tree-shaking.

hints.title: Testing
hints.content: Use Vue Test Utils for component testing, Vitest for unit testing. Test components in isolation, mock dependencies. Test computed properties, methods, and user interactions. Use shallow mounting for better performance.

hints.title: Vue Router Advanced
hints.content: Use route guards for authentication, lazy loading for code splitting, route meta for permissions, programmatic navigation with router.push(), route parameters and query strings, nested routes for complex layouts.

hints.title: Vuex Advanced Patterns
hints.content: Use modules for state organization, getters for computed state, actions for async operations, mutations for state changes. Implement plugins for logging, persistence. Use mapState, mapGetters, mapActions helpers.

hints.title: Pinia State Management
hints.content: Modern alternative to Vuex. Simpler API, better TypeScript support, devtools integration. Use stores for state, getters for computed values, actions for mutations. Automatic reactivity with Composition API.

hints.title: Vue 3 Composition API
hints.content: Use setup() function, reactive() for reactive data, ref() for primitives, computed() for derived state, watch() for side effects, lifecycle hooks (onMounted, onUpdated, onUnmounted). Better code organization and reusability.

hints.title: Vue Components Advanced
hints.content: Use slots for content distribution, scoped slots for flexible templates, dynamic components with <component :is="comp">, async components with defineAsyncComponent(), keep-alive for performance optimization.

hints.title: Vue Performance Optimization
hints.content: Use v-memo for expensive computations, keep-alive for component caching, lazy loading for routes, code splitting with dynamic imports, virtual scrolling for large lists, computed properties for expensive operations.

hints.title: Vue Animations
hints.content: Use <transition> for enter/leave animations, <transition-group> for list animations, animation classes (v-enter, v-enter-active, v-enter-to), JavaScript hooks (@enter, @after-enter), staggered animations with transition-group.

hints.title: Vue Directives
hints.content: Built-in: v-if/v-else/v-show for conditional rendering, v-for for lists, v-bind for attributes, v-on for events, v-model for two-way binding. Custom directives: bind, inserted, update, componentUpdated, unbind hooks.

hints.title: Vue Plugins
hints.content: Extend Vue functionality with plugins. Install with Vue.use(). Add global methods, directives, mixins, components. Examples: Vue Router, Vuex, Vue I18n, custom business logic plugins.

hints.title: Vue SSR
hints.content: Server-Side Rendering for better SEO and performance. Use Nuxt.js framework for simplified setup. Handle hydration, meta tags, routing. Critical CSS inlining, code splitting, progressive enhancement.

hints.title: Vue Accessibility
hints.content: Use semantic HTML, ARIA attributes, keyboard navigation, focus management. Test with screen readers. Follow WCAG guidelines. Use Vue A11y plugin for automated accessibility checks.

hints.title: Vue Internationalization
hints.content: Use Vue I18n plugin for multi-language support. Reactive locale switching, pluralization, date/number formatting. Lazy loading of translation files. RTL language support with CSS logical properties.

hints.title: Vue Best Practices
hints.content: Use Composition API for complex components, Options API for simple ones. Keep components small and focused. Use provide/inject for prop drilling. Implement proper error boundaries. Follow Vue style guide.

hints.title: Vue 3 Migration
hints.content: Update from Vue 2 to Vue 3: Composition API adoption, Vuex to Pinia migration, router changes, breaking changes handling. Use migration build for gradual upgrade. Update testing setup and build tools.

hints.title: Vue Ecosystem
hints.content: Nuxt.js for SSR/SPA, Quasar for cross-platform, Vuetify/Material Design for UI components, Vue CLI for scaffolding, Vite for fast development, Vue DevTools for debugging, Vue Use for composables.
