hints.title: useState Hook
hints.content: useState returns an array with current state and setter function. Use array destructuring: const [count, setCount] = useState(0). State updates are asynchronous.

hints.title: useEffect Hook
hints.content: useEffect runs after render and can handle side effects. Pass empty array [] as second argument to run only once (componentDidMount). Return cleanup function for componentWillUnmount.

hints.title: Props
hints.content: Props are read-only data passed from parent to child components. Use them to make components reusable. Destructure props in function parameters for cleaner code.

hints.title: Keys in Lists
hints.content: Keys help React identify which items have changed, been added, or removed. Use unique, stable identifiers (like IDs) rather than array indices for better performance.

hints.title: Custom Hooks
hints.content: Custom hooks let you extract component logic into reusable functions. They start with 'use' and can call other hooks. Use them to share stateful logic between components.

hints.title: useContext Hook
hints.content: useContext accesses context values without nesting. Create context with createContext(), provide with <Provider>, consume with useContext(Context). Alternative to prop drilling for global state.

hints.title: useReducer Hook
hints.content: useReducer is alternative to useState for complex state logic. Takes reducer function and initial state. Returns current state and dispatch function. Use for state machines or when next state depends on previous state.

hints.title: useMemo Hook
hints.content: useMemo memoizes expensive calculations. Only recalculates when dependencies change. Use for performance optimization. Similar to computed properties in other frameworks.

hints.title: useCallback Hook
hints.content: useCallback memoizes function references. Prevents unnecessary re-renders of child components. Pass stable function references to child components that depend on reference equality.

hints.title: useRef Hook
hints.content: useRef creates mutable references that persist across renders. Access DOM elements: const ref = useRef(null); <div ref={ref}>. Also used for storing values that don't trigger re-renders.

hints.title: React Router
hints.content: React Router handles client-side routing. Use <BrowserRouter>, <Routes>, <Route>. Navigate with <Link> or useNavigate(). Route parameters with useParams(). Query strings with useSearchParams().

hints.title: Context API
hints.content: Context provides way to pass data through component tree without prop drilling. Create context, provide value with Provider, consume with useContext or Consumer. Use for global state like theme, authentication.

hints.title: Error Boundaries
hints.content: Error boundaries catch JavaScript errors in component tree. Create class component with getDerivedStateFromError and componentDidCatch. Use <ErrorBoundary> wrapper to prevent app crashes.

hints.title: React.memo
hints.content: React.memo prevents re-renders if props haven't changed. Similar to shouldComponentUpdate. Use for performance optimization. Pass custom comparison function as second argument.

hints.title: React DevTools
hints.content: Browser extension for debugging React apps. Inspect component hierarchy, view props/state, profile performance. Use Profiler to measure render times. Check for unnecessary re-renders.

hints.title: React Router Advanced
hints.content: Use useNavigate for programmatic navigation, useParams for route parameters, useSearchParams for query strings, useLocation for current location, Outlet for nested routes, Navigate for redirects.

hints.title: React Context Advanced
hints.content: Use useContext for consuming context, createContext for creating providers, useReducer for complex state logic. Split contexts for performance. Use context selectors to prevent unnecessary re-renders.

hints.title: React Query/TanStack Query
hints.content: Powerful data fetching library. Handles caching, background updates, synchronization. Use useQuery for fetching, useMutation for mutations, useInfiniteQuery for pagination. Better than useEffect for server state.

hints.title: React Testing Library
hints.content: Testing utility focused on user interactions. Use render, screen, fireEvent, userEvent. Test user behavior, not implementation details. Query by accessible names, roles, labels. Follow testing best practices.

hints.title: React Performance Optimization
hints.content: Use React.memo for component memoization, useMemo for expensive computations, useCallback for function memoization, lazy loading with Suspense, code splitting with dynamic imports, virtual scrolling for large lists.

hints.title: React Forms
hints.content: Use controlled components with state, uncontrolled with refs. Handle form validation, submission, errors. Use react-hook-form for complex forms. Implement proper accessibility with labels, ARIA attributes.

hints.title: React Error Boundaries
hints.content: Catch JavaScript errors in component tree. Use componentDidCatch in class components, Error Boundary component wrapper. Display fallback UI. Log errors for monitoring. Don't use for async errors or event handlers.

hints.title: React Portals
hints.content: Render children into DOM node outside component tree. Use createPortal API. Useful for modals, tooltips, dropdowns. Maintains React event system. Consider accessibility and focus management.

hints.title: React Concurrent Features
hints.content: React 18 introduces concurrent rendering, automatic batching, Suspense improvements, startTransition for non-urgent updates. Use createRoot instead of render. Better user experience with non-blocking updates.

hints.title: React Server Components
hints.content: Render components on server, reducing client bundle size. Use 'use client' directive for client components. Server components can access databases directly. Better performance and SEO. Framework-specific implementation.

hints.title: React Accessibility
hints.content: Use semantic HTML, ARIA attributes, keyboard navigation, focus management. Test with screen readers. Follow WCAG guidelines. Use react-aria or headeless UI libraries for accessible components.

hints.title: React State Management
hints.content: Use useState for local state, useReducer for complex state, Context for global state, Zustand/Redux for large applications. Consider state colocation with component composition. Avoid prop drilling.

hints.title: React Best Practices
hints.content: Use functional components with hooks, keep components small and focused, use custom hooks for logic reuse, implement proper error boundaries, use TypeScript for type safety, follow React style guide.

hints.title: React Ecosystem
hints.content: Next.js for SSR/SPA, Create React App for quick setup, Vite for fast development, Material-UI/Ant Design for components, React Router for routing, Redux Toolkit for state, React Query for data fetching.

hints.title: React Modern Patterns
hints.content: Use compound components pattern, render props, higher-order components, custom hooks. Implement proper loading and error states. Use Suspense for async operations. Follow single responsibility principle.

quiz.question: When does useEffect run by default?
quiz.explanation: useEffect runs after every completed render, including the initial render. Use dependency array to control when it runs.

quiz.question: What is the correct way to update state based on previous state?
quiz.explanation: Both approaches work, but using the functional update form ensures you're working with the latest state value.

quiz.question: Which hook is used to perform side effects in functional components?
quiz.explanation: useEffect is the primary hook for handling side effects like API calls, subscriptions, and DOM manipulation.

quiz.question: What happens if you don't provide a key prop when rendering a list?
options: React will use array indices as keys
quiz.explanation: React will use array indices as keys if none are provided, but this can cause performance issues and bugs with list reordering.

quiz.question: Which lifecycle method is equivalent to useEffect with an empty dependency array?
quiz.explanation: useEffect with empty dependency array [] runs only once after the initial render, equivalent to componentDidMount.

quiz.question: What is the purpose of the 'key' prop in React lists?
options: To help React identify changed items
quiz.explanation: Keys help React identify which items changed, been added, or removed, and improve performance by reducing unnecessary re-renders.

quiz.question: Which hook is used to access context in functional components?
quiz.explanation: useContext hook allows functional components to subscribe to React context without nesting.

quiz.question: What does useMemo do?
quiz.explanation: useMemo memoizes the result of expensive calculations and only recalculates when dependencies change.

quiz.question: Which of the following is NOT a valid React hook?
quiz.explanation: useQuery is not a built-in React hook. It's commonly used in data fetching libraries like React Query, but not part of core React.

quiz.question: What is the correct way to handle form input in React?
quiz.explanation: Both controlled (using state) and uncontrolled (using refs) components are valid ways to handle form input in React.

quiz.question: Which component is used to render different components based on a route?
quiz.explanation: <Routes> is used in React Router v6 to render the first child <Route> that matches the current location.

quiz.question: What is the purpose of React.memo?
options: To prevent re-renders when props haven't changed
quiz.explanation: React.memo is a higher-order component that memoizes the component, preventing re-renders when props haven't changed.

quiz.question: Which hook is used for side effects in React?
quiz.explanation: useEffect is the primary hook for handling side effects like API calls, subscriptions, and DOM manipulation in functional components.

quiz.question: What is JSX?
quiz.explanation: JSX stands for JavaScript XML and allows you to write HTML-like syntax in JavaScript that gets compiled to React.createElement calls.

quiz.question: Which method is called when a component is removed from the DOM?
quiz.explanation: The cleanup function returned from useEffect is called when the component is unmounted, equivalent to componentWillUnmount in class components.

quiz.question: Which hook is used for side effects?
quiz.explanation: useEffect is used for side effects like data fetching, subscriptions, or DOM manipulation. It runs after render.

quiz.question: What is the purpose of useCallback?
quiz.explanation: useCallback memoizes functions to prevent unnecessary re-renders of child components that depend on those functions.

quiz.question: Which hook manages global state?
quiz.explanation: useContext is used to consume context values that are provided by a Context.Provider higher up in the component tree.

quiz.question: What does React.memo do?
quiz.explanation: React.memo prevents re-renders of functional components if their props haven't changed, similar to shouldComponentUpdate.

quiz.question: Which hook is used for form handling?
quiz.explanation: useState is commonly used for form handling in React, managing input values and form state.

quiz.question: What is JSX?
quiz.explanation: JSX stands for JavaScript XML and allows you to write HTML-like syntax in JavaScript that gets compiled to React.createElement calls.

quiz.question: Which hook is used for async operations?
quiz.explanation: useEffect is commonly used for async operations like data fetching, although libraries like React Query provide better abstractions.

quiz.question: What is the virtual DOM?
quiz.explanation: Virtual DOM is a lightweight JavaScript representation of the actual DOM that React uses to optimize updates and improve performance.

quiz.question: Which method renders React to DOM?
quiz.explanation: createRoot() from react-dom/client is the modern way to render React applications in React 18.

quiz.question: What is the purpose of keys in lists?
quiz.explanation: Keys help React identify which items have changed, are added, or are removed, improving performance and maintaining component state.

quiz.question: Which hook is used for complex state logic?
quiz.explanation: useReducer is used for complex state logic that involves multiple sub-values or when the next state depends on the previous one.

quiz.question: What is React Router used for?
quiz.explanation: React Router is used for declarative routing in React applications, allowing navigation between different components.

quiz.question: Which lifecycle method is deprecated?
quiz.explanation: componentWillMount was deprecated in React 16.3 and removed in React 17. Use componentDidMount instead.

quiz.question: What is the purpose of useMemo?
quiz.explanation: useMemo memoizes expensive computations so they don't run on every render if their dependencies haven't changed.

quiz.question: Which tool is used for React testing?
quiz.explanation: Jest, Mocha, and Jasmine can all be used for testing React applications, with Jest being the most commonly used with Create React App.

angular.name: Angular
angular.description: Angular framework concepts and best practices

hints.title: Components vs Directives
hints.content: Components are directives with a template. Components control a portion of the screen called a view. Directives are instructions in the DOM - structural directives (ngIf, ngFor) change DOM layout, attribute directives (ngStyle, ngClass) change appearance/behavior.

hints.title: Dependency Injection
hints.content: Angular's DI system provides dependencies to components. Use @Injectable() decorator for services. Inject dependencies in constructor parameters. Angular creates singletons for services by default. Use providedIn: 'root' for automatic tree-shaking.

hints.title: Change Detection
hints.content: Angular uses zone.js to detect changes. OnPush strategy checks for changes only when input properties change or events are explicitly triggered. Use async pipe for observables, trackBy function for ngFor to optimize performance.

hints.title: RxJS & Observables
hints.content: Angular heavily uses RxJS for reactive programming. Use Observable for async operations. Common operators: map, filter, tap, switchMap, combineLatest. Subscribe in ngOnInit, unsubscribe in ngOnDestroy to prevent memory leaks.

hints.title: Angular CLI Commands
hints.content: ng new creates new app, ng generate component/directive/service/pipe creates code. ng serve starts dev server, ng build builds for production. ng test runs unit tests, ng e2e runs end-to-end tests. Use --skip-tests to skip test files.

hints.title: Angular Modules
hints.content: @NgModule decorator defines module with declarations (components, directives, pipes), imports (other modules), exports (public declarations), providers (services), bootstrap (root component).

hints.title: Pipes
hints.content: Pipes transform data in templates. Built-in: DatePipe, CurrencyPipe, JsonPipe, SlicePipe. Create custom pipes with @Pipe decorator. Use pure pipes for stateless transformations, impure for stateful.

hints.title: Forms
hints.content: Template-driven forms use directives in template. Reactive forms use FormBuilder in component. Use FormControl, FormGroup, FormArray. Validators provide validation. ngForm directive manages form state.

hints.title: HTTP Client
hints.content: HttpClientModule provides HTTP functionality. Use HttpClient for GET, POST, PUT, DELETE requests. Handle responses with subscribe() or async pipe. Use interceptors for request/response modification.

hints.title: Testing
hints.content: Use TestBed for component testing. Karma + Jasmine for unit tests. Use async() or fakeAsync() for async testing. Mock services with jasmine.createSpyObj(). Test components in isolation.

hints.title: Angular Universal
hints.content: Server-side rendering for Angular. Improves SEO, initial load time. Use @nguniversal/express-engine. Prerender static pages. Handle browser-specific APIs with isPlatformBrowser().

hints.title: Angular Material
hints.content: UI component library following Material Design. Use mat-button, mat-card, mat-form-field. Import MatButtonModule, MatCardModule. Customize themes with angular.json. Responsive breakpoints.

hints.title: Lazy Loading
hints.content: Load modules only when needed. Use loadChildren in routes. Reduces initial bundle size. Improves app performance. Use preloading strategies for critical modules.

hints.title: Security
hints.content: Use Angular's built-in security features. DomSanitizer for safe HTML/CSS. Avoid innerHTML with user input. Use HTTPS. Implement authentication guards. Validate form inputs. Use Content Security Policy.

hints.title: Performance
hints.content: Use OnPush change detection strategy. Use trackBy in ngFor. Avoid unnecessary subscriptions. Use lazy loading. Minimize watchers. Use pure pipes. Profile with Angular DevTools.

hints.title: Angular Router Advanced
hints.content: Use route guards (CanActivate, CanDeactivate), resolvers for data preloading, route parameters, query parameters, fragments. Implement lazy loading, preloading strategies, route animations.

hints.title: Angular Reactive Forms
hints.content: Use FormBuilder, FormGroup, FormControl, FormArray. Implement custom validators, async validators, dynamic forms. Handle form submission, validation errors, disabled states. Use valueChanges for reactive updates.

hints.title: Angular HTTP Client
hints.content: Use HttpClient for REST API calls. Implement interceptors for authentication, logging, error handling. Use HttpClientModule. Handle different response types, error handling, retry logic.

hints.title: Angular Testing
hints.content: Use TestBed for component testing, Jasmine for test framework, Karma for test runner. Test components, services, pipes, directives. Mock dependencies, test async operations, test user interactions.

hints.title: Angular Animations
hints.content: Use @angular/animations package. Define triggers, states, transitions, keyframes. Use animation metadata in components. Implement enter/leave animations, stagger effects, parallel/sequential animations.

hints.title: Angular PWA
hints.content: Use Angular Service Worker for offline functionality, caching strategies, background sync. Implement push notifications. Use @angular/pwa schematics. Configure web app manifest for installable apps.

hints.title: Angular State Management
hints.content: Use NgRx for complex state management, Akita for simpler solutions. Implement actions, reducers, selectors, effects. Use @ngrx/store, @ngrx/effects, @ngrx/entity for entity management.

hints.title: Angular Internationalization
hints.content: Use @angular/localize for i18n. Extract messages with ng extract-i18n. Configure locales. Use currency, date, number pipes with locale. Handle RTL languages and cultural differences.

hints.title: Angular Accessibility
hints.content: Follow WCAG guidelines. Use semantic HTML, ARIA attributes, keyboard navigation. Test with screen readers. Implement focus management, skip links, proper form labels. Use ngAria for automatic accessibility.

hints.title: Angular Best Practices
hints.content: Use Angular CLI for project setup. Follow Angular style guide. Use OnPush change detection. Implement proper error handling. Use TypeScript strict mode. Write unit tests. Use linting and formatting.

hints.title: Angular Architecture
hints.content: Use feature modules for organization. Implement core/shared modules. Use barrel exports. Separate concerns with services. Use dependency injection. Implement proper component communication patterns.

hints.title: Angular Deployment
hints.content: Build for production with ng build --prod. Use Ahead-of-Time compilation. Enable tree shaking. Optimize bundle size. Configure CI/CD pipelines. Deploy to various platforms (Firebase, Netlify, AWS, etc.).

hints.title: Angular Ecosystem
hints.content: Angular CLI for scaffolding, Angular Material for UI components, Angular Universal for SSR, RxJS for reactive programming, NgRx for state management, Angular Testing Library for testing utilities.

hints.title: Angular Migration
hints.content: Update from older versions to latest. Use Angular Update Guide. Handle breaking changes. Update dependencies. Test thoroughly. Use codelyzer for migration assistance. Plan for gradual migration.

hints.title: Angular Modern Features
hints.content: Standalone components, new control flow syntax (@if, @for, @switch), inject() function, signals for reactivity, better hydration, improved performance, enhanced developer experience with Angular DevTools.

quiz.question: What is the purpose of the @Component decorator in Angular?
options: To mark a class as a component and provide metadata
quiz.explanation: The @Component decorator tells Angular that the class is a component and provides configuration metadata including selector, template, and styles.

quiz.question: Which directive is used for two-way data binding in Angular?
quiz.explanation: [(ngModel)] is the two-way data binding syntax in Angular. It combines property binding [] and event binding () for bidirectional data flow.

quiz.question: What is the correct way to inject a service in Angular?
quiz.explanation: Angular recommends constructor injection for services. Add the service as a parameter in the component constructor, and Angular's DI system will provide the instance.

quiz.question: Which lifecycle hook is called after Angular has initialized all data-bound properties?
quiz.explanation: ngOnInit is called once after the first ngOnChanges and is the ideal place to initialize component data, fetch data from services, and set up subscriptions.

quiz.question: What is the purpose of the async pipe in Angular?
quiz.explanation: The async pipe subscribes to an Observable or Promise automatically and returns the latest value. It also unsubscribes when the component is destroyed, preventing memory leaks.

quiz.question: Which directive is used for conditional rendering in Angular?
quiz.explanation: *ngIf for conditional rendering, *ngFor for lists, and *ngSwitch for multiple conditions are all structural directives in Angular.

quiz.question: What is the correct way to handle HTTP errors in Angular?
quiz.explanation: Angular provides multiple ways to handle HTTP errors including try-catch, .catch() operator, and HttpErrorResponse class.

quiz.question: Which lifecycle hook is called after a component's view has been initialized?
quiz.explanation: ngAfterViewInit is called after Angular has fully initialized the component's view and child views.

quiz.question: What does the 'trackBy' function do in ngFor?
quiz.explanation: trackBy helps Angular track which items have changed and improves performance by reducing DOM manipulations.

quiz.question: Which of the following is used for two-way data binding in Angular?
quiz.explanation: [(ngModel)] creates two-way data binding, combining property binding [] and event binding () syntax.

quiz.question: What is the purpose of the @Injectable decorator?
options: To mark a class as available for dependency injection
quiz.explanation: @Injectable decorator marks a class as available to be provided and injected as a dependency in Angular's DI system.

quiz.question: Which operator is used to cancel previous HTTP requests in Angular?
quiz.explanation: switchMap cancels previous ongoing HTTP requests and only returns the latest one, preventing race conditions.

quiz.question: What is the correct way to create a custom pipe in Angular?
quiz.explanation: Custom pipes require @Pipe decorator and implement PipeTransform interface. The CLI command ng generate pipe creates the boilerplate.

quiz.question: Which change detection strategy improves performance?
quiz.explanation: OnPush change detection strategy only checks for changes when input properties change or events are explicitly triggered, improving performance.

quiz.question: What is the purpose of Angular's environment files?
quiz.explanation: Environment files (environment.ts, environment.prod.ts) store configuration like API URLs, feature flags, and other environment-specific settings.

quiz.question: Which CLI command creates a new Angular component?
quiz.explanation: ng generate component creates a new Angular component with all necessary files (component, template, styles, test).

quiz.question: What is the purpose of HttpClientModule?
quiz.explanation: HttpClientModule provides HttpClient for making HTTP requests to REST APIs with features like interceptors, error handling, and typed responses.

quiz.question: Which decorator is used for services?
quiz.explanation: @Injectable decorator marks a class as available for dependency injection. It's used for services that may have their own dependencies.

quiz.question: What is the purpose of ngOnInit?
quiz.explanation: ngOnInit is called once after the component is initialized and its inputs are set. It's commonly used for data fetching and initialization logic.

quiz.question: Which directive is used for conditional rendering?
quiz.explanation: *ngIf conditionally includes or removes an element from the DOM based on the expression value.

quiz.question: What is the purpose of ReactiveFormsModule?
quiz.explanation: ReactiveFormsModule provides reactive forms with FormBuilder, FormGroup, and FormControl classes for programmatic form management.

quiz.question: Which lifecycle hook is called after view initialization?
quiz.explanation: ngAfterViewInit is called after the component's view and child views have been initialized. Use it for DOM-dependent initialization.

quiz.question: What is the purpose of ViewChild?
quiz.explanation: ViewChild is used to get references to child components, directives, or DOM elements within the component's template.

quiz.question: Which operator is used for async operations in Angular?
quiz.explanation: subscribe() is used to execute observables and handle their emissions. It's essential for working with async operations in Angular.

quiz.question: What is the purpose of CanActivate guard?
quiz.explanation: CanActivate guard is used to protect routes by checking if a user can access them, typically used for authentication checks.

quiz.question: Which command builds Angular for production?
quiz.explanation: ng build --prod builds the application with production optimizations including AOT compilation, tree shaking, and bundle optimization.

quiz.question: What is the purpose of trackBy in ngFor?
quiz.explanation: trackBy function helps Angular track which items have changed in a list, improving performance by avoiding unnecessary DOM manipulations.

quiz.question: Which lifecycle hook is called before component destruction?
quiz.explanation: ngOnDestroy is called just before the component is destroyed, used for cleanup like unsubscribing from observables or clearing timers.

quiz.question: What is the purpose of async pipe?
quiz.explanation: async pipe automatically subscribes to observables and unsubscribes when the component is destroyed, displaying the latest value.

quiz.question: Which tool is used for Angular testing?
quiz.explanation: Angular uses Karma as the test runner, Jasmine as the testing framework, and supports various assertion libraries for comprehensive testing.
